event.title: Faculty Biennial Exhibition 2015
event.description_text:
The faculty biennial, a longstanding tradition, showcases new work by the extraordinary artists and designers who teach at the Rhode Island School of Design (RISD). The works on view are as varied as the many departments and divisions in which the faculty teach—ranging from apparel, textiles, painting, printmaking, ceramics, glass, sculpture, illustration, photography, jewelry, and metalsmithing to graphic design, industrial design, architecture, landscape architecture, interior architecture, film, animation, digital media, furniture, and more.

This year, the Museum offers an expanded opportunity for RISD faculty to share their works of art and design in the exhibition or present their research and expertise as teaching artists in a Faculty Forum. In this new forum, faculty members offer discussions, readings, papers, and performances—creating an exciting platform for public engagement.
event.address: Chace Center, 2nd floor, 20 North Main Street, Providence, RI

event.title: RISD Exhibtionists Present: NEXT FALL
event.description_text:
The RISD Exhibitionists, the only student run and organized theatre group on campus, present Geoffery Nauffts' Tony nominated play, NEXT FALL.

A witty and provocative look at faith, commitment and unconditional love, the story focuses on the five year relationship of Luke and Adam, a Christian and an Atheist, respectively. The play forces us to examine what it means to "believe" and what it might cost us not to.

Free tickets here.

event.title: Live Animal Study 2015
event.description_text:
Bring your sketchbooks, pencils, and light painting supplies and enjoy a rare opportunity to study a handful of live exotic (and some not-so-exotic) animals up close and personal! Seasoned Humane Educator and RISD alumna Laurelin Sitterly [03 IL] will present on each creature's basic anatomy, movement, and habits that will be sure to inspire you and provide a wealth of knowledge for your animal-themed projects. Taxidermy and skeletal models will also be available to examine, courtesy of RISD's Edna Lawrence Nature Lab. This is an event to gather inspiration from the animal world, practice your craft amidst an active environment, network with other artists, and raise funds for some great organizations.

Live Animal Study 2015Sunday, February 22rd, 20141:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m.The Edna Lawrence Nature Lab at RISD, 13 Waterman St., Providence, RITickets: $15 at https://liveanimalstudy2015.eventbrite.com 

All proceeds from this program will be donated to area animal shelters: RISPCA and Sweet Binks Rabbit Rescue. Advance registration is required and limited to 25 participants.

Questions? Please contact workshop coordinator Christina Rodriguez [03 IL] at crodrigu@risd.edu.

event.title: RISD LEADS - From Harlym to Higher Ed
event.description_text:
Featuring: Jamele Adams, Dean of Students at Brandeis University (biography)

The art of communication is the crux of our human community, let us exercise it! How does one from a single parent household in Harlem, New York City navigate the world in such a way to become a Dean in Higher Education? Furthermore, what role did poetry play in the development of self-esteem, voice, and developing  ways to connect with people to advocate for us all to connect with each other even more? Join Brandeis University Dean of Students and slam poet Jamele Adams as he shares his journey from Harlym to Higher Ed as a case study in leadership and the art of communication.

Fulfills - Communication

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Orit Hofshi - Printmaking Sponsored Lecture
event.description_text:
Orit Hofshi, born in 1959, is currently working at “Mishkan Omanim” (The Artist’s Studio) in Herzliya , Israel, following a decade of studying, working and exhibiting in the US. Orit, who has received her MA in Arts from Leeds University, UK, first studied in the Wizo College of Design in Israel. Upon graduating, she continued her studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia, where she majored in painting and printmaking.

Since the mid 90’s, Orit has focused on works on paper, installations and woodcutting as her primary mediator, exploring the relationship between the artist, topographical patterns and her perception of the environment and man.

http://www.orithofshi.com

event.title: Black Maria Film Festival
event.description_text:
Black Maria Film Festival

Monday, February 23 at 7:00 PM

RISD Auditorium, Free Admission
 

Screening Program:

Pirate Named Ned by Steve Gentile - 8:00

Sound Print by Monteith McCollum - 7:00

Without a Doubt by Gerald Guthrie - 6:00

Consider the Ant by Emily Fraser - 11:00

Swallowed Whole by Heidi Kumao - 4:00

Steel Mill Rolling by Ross Nugent - 12:00

Umbrella House by Catalina Santamaria - 10:00

A Thousand Miles from the Sea by Marta Renzi - 12:00

Lightning in the Hand by Joey Grossfield - 15:00
** filmmakers Joey Grossfield & Andrew Reuland will be in attendance for a Q&A

Where We Stand by Lindsay McIntyre - 5:00

Self Portrait Portrait by James Hollenbaugh - 6:00

Ballad of Holland Island House by Lynn Tomlinson - 4:00


Since 1981, the annual Black Maria Film and Video Festival, an international juried competition and award tour, has been fulfilling its mission to advocate, exhibit and reward cutting edge works from independent filmmakers and videomakers. The festival is known for its national public exhibition program, which features a variety of bold contemporary works drawn from the annual collection of 50 award winning films and videos.

event.title: Fulbright Workshop
event.description_text: RISD is one of the top producing Fulbright programs in the United States for this prestigious grant! Be sure to take advantage of this remarkable award opportunity. Propose a year-long creative project in one of 140+ countries. Open to all disciplines and all kinds of projects. Rising juniors, seniors, graduate students, and recent alumni can apply through RISD (applicants must be U.S. citizens). This workshop will provide you with insights, tips, and advice about the application process. You’ll also hear from current, successful Fulbright applicants about their proposal development experience.  Lindsay Carone, MFA Sculpture 2013, and Alice Taranto, BFA Graphic Design 2015, will be joining us to talk about their application experience. AND, Acacia Johnson, BFA Photography 2014, who is currently on her Fulbright grant will be calling in to say hello from…the Canadian High Arctic!

event.title: Artisan-Toolmaker Panel Discussion
event.description_text:
This is the first of a three part forum, "tool()," taking place throughout the spring. The forum takes stock of a range and combination of tools – traditional and novel, analog and digital – which meaningfully engage the creative minds of today. This event will convene a wide audience including practitioners pushing the frontier of current modes of artistic and design production, students and academics who integrate learning and teaching with toolmaking, and industry players who are developing these tools of trade for widespread use. The tool() forum is an opportunity to understand the evolving dynamic between increasingly powerful tools and the empowerment of artists and designers.

 

About the Artisan-Toolmaker session: In most creative pursuits, the nature of one’s tools is intimately related to the object of creation. Rather than accept conventional disciplinary groupings of preexisting tools, this session values the kind of discipline that emerges from intense focus on craft and technique. The question this session poses is not "what is the best tool?" but rather, "what is the most meaningful, novel, strange, or provocative tool?" Faculty will embody the gradient that exists between the toolmaker and the artisan, showcasing both those who make invisible tools as well as those whose tools pervade the very subject matter of their work. This session will emphasize line, abstraction and procedure–common ground between artists and designers–which mediate the cold neutrality of the tool with the intuitive presence of the author.

 

The discussion is moderated by Aaron Forrest (Department of Architecture) and Carl Lostritto (Department of Architecture).

Keynote speaker Luke Ogrydziak (OPA) will be joined by panelists:

John Caserta (Department of Graphic Design)

Kai Franz (Division of Foundation Studies)

Stefanie Pender (Division of Foundation Studies)

Andrew Raftery (Department of Printmaking)

more information at risdtool.org

This is the first of a three part forum, "tool()," taking place throughout the spring. The forum takes stock of a range and combination of tools – traditional and novel, analog and digital – which meaningfully engage the creative minds of today. This event will convene a wide audience including practitioners pushing the frontier of current modes of artistic and design production, students and academics who integrate learning and teaching with toolmaking, and industry players who are developing these tools of trade for widespread use. The tool() forum is an opportunity to understand the evolving dynamic between increasingly powerful tools and the empowerment of artists and designers.

 

About the Artisan-Toolmaker session: In most creative pursuits, the nature of one’s tools is intimately related to the object of creation. Rather than accept conventional disciplinary groupings of preexisting tools, this session values the kind of discipline that emerges from intense focus on craft and technique. The question this session poses is not "what is the best tool?" but rather, "what is the most meaningful, novel, strange, or provocative tool?" Faculty will embody the gradient that exists between the toolmaker and the artisan, showcasing both those who make invisible tools as well as those whose tools pervade the very subject matter of their work. This session will emphasize line, abstraction and procedure–common ground between artists and designers–which mediate the cold neutrality of the tool with the intuitive presence of the author.

 

The discussion is moderated by Aaron Forrest (Department of Architecture) and Carl Lostritto (Department of Architecture).

Keynote speaker Luke Ogrydziak (OPA) will be joined by panelists:

John Caserta (Department of Graphic Design)

Kai Franz (Division of Foundation Studies)

Stefanie Pender (Division of Foundation Studies)

Andrew Raftery (Department of Printmaking)

more information at risdtool.org

event.title: YouTubing for Change
event.description_text:
A diversity panel and lecture series hosted by BAAD, in collaboration with RISD Feminists, ISE, CSI, Liberal Arts, and the Mapping Identities Initiative. 

RISD is proud to welcome three popular YouTubers to participate in "Youtubing for Change" Akilah Hughes, Jenny Yang, and Jamie Kilstein address social issues of race, gender, sexuality and orientation using their platforms. This event will allow for a Q&A session.

This event fulfills both RISD Feminist's and BAAD's goal to raise awareness through facilitating dialogue on campus and letting people know that these issues are discussions that they can and should be having.

This event is free and open to the public. Contact (ise@risd.edu) for more information.

event.title: Luke Ogrydziak Lecture
event.description_text:
Luke Ogrydziak is a partner and co-founder of Ogrydziak Prillinger Architects (OPA). He studied at Princeton University, where he received both his Bachelor of Arts in Architecture summa cum laude in 1992, and his Master of Architecture degree in 1995. At Princeton, he received the Shellman Award for architectural representation.

OPA is a progressive San Francisco-based office that has been globally recognized for projects ranging in scale from institutions to private homes, as well as interior and object design. Founded in 2004, OPA is an idea-driven office committed to finding design solutions that both expand the possibilities inherent in architecture and resonate within their particular context. While every project originates as a response to specific requirements of site, program and client, it evolves as an exploration of its own internal potential rather than reflecting a predetermined architectural style. In all the work, there is an emphasis on shaping and choreographing spatial experiences through the consideration of movement, perception and formal logic. As a result, the work is distinctive for its conceptual clarity and strong visual presence.

 

Ogrydziak will also be particpating in the Artisian Toolmaker panel discussion, which is part of the tool() forum, on Wednesday 2/25

event.title: Avi Schaefer Interfaith Shabbat
event.description_text:
In the spirit of the Sabbath and honoring engagement during the period of Lent, we welcome you to the Interfaith Avi Shabbat on Friday, February 27 at Brown RISD Hillel. This annual program honors the memory of Avi Schaefer '13, who was passionate about interfaith and cross-cultural understanding. The evening aspires to offer opportunity for substantive interfaith exchange, including words from campus faith leaders and a performance by the Harmonizing Grace Gospel choir during dinner. Avi Shabbat is a collaboration between Brown RISD Hillel, the Office of the Chaplains and Religious Life, Brown RISD Catholic Community, Brown Protestant Community, Brown Muslim Students Association and the Religious Literacy Project. 

Service options @ 6:15pm: Havurah (Beit Midrash) & Reform (Student Lounge);
7:30pm Blessings and Announcements (Lobby) and Dinner (Social Hall)

 

(please feel free to attend only part or all of the evening!)

event.title: RISD LEADS - Gender at Work
event.description_text:
Featuring: Jennifer Prewitt-Freilino, Professor of Psychology at RISD (biography)

Although the dynamics of modern life are a far cry from the dichotomous 1950s American model of men as breadwinner and woman as homemaker, evidence from around the globe suggests that women and men do not face an equal playing field when it comes to obtaining and maintaining positions of power and status. In this seminar, we will discuss how gender stereotypes and norms, laws and policies, economic systems, and reproductive choice all factor into the realities that both men and women face when trying to balance work and home life, and the implications that has for individuals seeking positions of leadership.

Fulfills - Inclusion/Diversity, Theory

 

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: RISD Photo TC Colley Lecture Series - Artie Vierkant
event.description_text: Artie Vierkant was born in 1986 in Brainderd, Minnesota. He lives and works in New York. Vierkant received his MFA from the University of California San Diego in 2012. He has had recent solo exhibitions at UNTITLED, New York (2014), Higher Pictures, New York (2014), New Galerie, Paris (2013), and Exile, Berlin (2013). He has also recently participated in group exhibitions at galleries and institutions including Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, Beijing, China (2014), International Center of Photography, New York (2014), UNTITLED, New York (2013), Fonds M-Arco, Marseille, France (2013), Institute of Contemporary Art London (2012), and Carlos/Ishikawa, London (2012).

event.title: Faculty Biennial Exhibition 2015
event.description_text:
The faculty biennial, a longstanding tradition, showcases new work by the extraordinary artists and designers who teach at the Rhode Island School of Design (RISD). The works on view are as varied as the many departments and divisions in which the faculty teach—ranging from apparel, textiles, painting, printmaking, ceramics, glass, sculpture, illustration, photography, jewelry, and metalsmithing to graphic design, industrial design, architecture, landscape architecture, interior architecture, film, animation, digital media, furniture, and more.

This year, the Museum offers an expanded opportunity for RISD faculty to share their works of art and design in the exhibition or present their research and expertise as teaching artists in a Faculty Forum. In this new forum, faculty members offer discussions, readings, papers, and performances—creating an exciting platform for public engagement.

event.title: What Companies Want from Employees / Business 101 Workshop
event.description_text: Many students create work that they think may have commercial potential; but moving that idea, that first prototype, into a reality is a long journey that requires some fundamental understanding of business: marketing, manufacturing, distributing and selling a product to a customer. The objective of this four-hour seminar is to give you an introduction to the fundamentals of business so you leave with basic knowledge about how to convert your idea into a reality. You’ll gain tools and frameworks to consider whether or not an entrepreneurial venture is even a possibility. And, if you choose not to pursue an enterprise, you’ll have frameworks and concepts that you can use to think through other professional opportunities. Also, lunch will be served!

event.title: RISD LEADS - Alternative Forms of Activist Feminist Leadership
event.description_text:
Featuring: Gail Cohee, Director, Sarah Doyle Women's Center; Adjunct Professor, Gender and Sexuality Studies at Brown University (biography)

This session will address ways in which leadership can operate in feminist, activist organizations without duplicating models that perpetuate patriarchal or oppressive structures. We will explore leadership in non-hierarchical, collaborative ways while cultivating ideas for transforming our own leadership styles

Fulfills - Operational, Inclusion/Diversity

 

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Color Management for Graphic Designers Webinar
event.description_text:
Color Management for Graphic Designers & Fine Art Professionals: What every designer and artist needs to know about managing color with Martha DiMeo, Digital Imaging and Photoshop SpecialistTuesday, March 10, 20156:30 p.m. - 7:30 p.m. ESTFees: $12 RISD Alumni, CE + Friends; $0 RISD StudentsRegistration: http://www.cvent.com/d/prqkfl/1Q  

There is no escaping it. If you are a print designer, web designer, illustrator, or fine artist—and you desire accurate, consistent, and predictable color reproduction—a color-managed workflow is essential. In this hour-long webinar, Digital Imaging Specialist Martha DiMeo will demystify the process and introduce you to 3 key components of implementing a color-managed workflow: display calibration and profiling, embedding and honoring profiles, and the importance of controlling your  physical work environment.

You will come away with an understanding of color management's role in the digital color workflow and the necessary steps to achieve consistent, predictable, and repeatable color from capture to final output. 

Bonus for Painters & Illustrators: Very often, artists are disappointed when they see their artwork printed. Accurately reproducing the color in paintings and other fine art pieces presents its own unique set of challenges. Following the main talk, there will be a brief post discussion on art reproduction. If your artwork is reproduced in books, gallery catalogs, or printed on postcards and other promotional material, you’ll want to stick around for this follow-up conversation.

event.title: RISD LEADS - Creating Space: Utilizing Adaptive Leadership to Break Down Barriers and Increase Flexibility
event.description_text:
Featuring: Digit Murphy, Head Coach of the Boston Blades, Canadian Women’s Hockey League (biography)

Digit Murphy, current head coach of the only US professional women’s hockey team (Boston Blades) and the winningest coach in Division I women’s ice hockey history (Brown University), will share her personal history of leadership and lessons she learned along the way.  As a woman working in a historically male-centric industry and sport, Digit will share the real world techniques that she has utilized to move forward, generate success, and not get discouraged.  Her persistence and willingness to create civil controversy have provided her with essential skills around understanding personal context in order to adaptively move toward success.  Attendees will leave this session with a better understanding of why it is important to avoid “tunnel vision” and constricting roles so that they can see the big picture and adapt to meet new circumstances.  Students will be able to take Digit’s story of adapting her leadership styles to succeed in hostile or inequitable environments and apply it to any situation or challenge they face as leaders.

Fulfills - Inclusion/Diversity, Cultural, Operational

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Mark West Lecture
event.description_text:
Mark West is internationally recognized as the inventor of numerous methods for casting concrete structures in flexible formworks. His first experiments in this area (1986) have led to a series of full-scale constructions of fabric-formed structures in Canada, the United States, Chile, and Puerto Rico. This technical research has been accompanied by exhibitions of drawings, photographs, and built installations exploring the future of architectural design. His research has been widely published and presented to architectural, civil engineering, and construction industry conferences internationally. 

His research has led to a growing network of associated research projects around the world.

event.title: Career Resources for Freshman
event.description_text:
As a Freshman your career path has begun and will be developing throughout your time at RISD. Find out what resources are available to you from career advising to LinkedIn networking to our internship database ArtWorks as well as numerous career-focused websites. Discover how to establish your career profile; develop a resume; and post your work at RISD Portfolios.

For this event, the Career Center is partnering with RISD 360, the First Year programming series. You will get to meet some upper classmen peer mentors who can offer advice and experience working with the Career Center and how they utilize the tools offered by them to their advantage.

event.title: RISD Photo TC Colley Lecture Series - Atul Bhalla
event.description_text:
Atul Bhalla has explored the physical, historical, spiritual, and political significance of water to the urban environment and population of his city (New Delhi) through artworks that incorporate sculpture, painting, installation, video, photography, and performance.

 

Bhalla is particularly concerned about the relationship between the Yamuna and urban communities. The Yamuna is one of the largest tributaries of the Ganges River and tens of millions of people depend on its water for irrigation, and municipal/domestic use. Venerated in Hindu mythology as the goddess of life, it is also one of the most polluted rivers in the world. With a focus on pollution and scarcity of water, Yamuna Walk traces the artist’s five-day walk around the portion of the river that encircles New Delhi. At times through this journey Bhalla was forced to climb fences and cross concrete overpasses to continue his quest. These modern obstacles weave their way into the fabric of rural life— connecting and hampering its development as well as continuation.

 

Atul Bhalla earned his BFA from Delhi University and his MFA from the School of Art of Northern Illinois University. His work has been in several museum exhibitions, most notably in The Newark Museum’s “INDIA: Public Places, Private Spaces” and the Fotographie Forum Frankfurt’s “Watching me – Watching India: New Photography from India,” and the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum Triennial and at the Harvard Art Museums. He is currently associate professor at the Shiv Nadar University Greater Noida. India.

The works on view are as varied as the many departments and divisions in which the faculty teach—ranging from apparel, textiles, painting, printmaking, ceramics, glass, sculpture, illustration, photography, jewelry, and metalsmithing to graphic design, industrial design, architecture, landscape architecture, interior architecture, film, animation, digital media, furniture, and more.

This year, the Museum offers an expanded opportunity for RISD faculty to share their works of art and design in the exhibition or present their research and expertise as teaching artists in a Faculty Forum. In this new forum, faculty members offer discussions, readings, papers, and performances—creating an exciting platform for public engagement.

event.title: 2015 National Art Education Association Convention Reception
event.description_text:
RISD is going to be everywhere at the 2015 National Art Education Association Convention in New Orleans! On Friday, March 27, RISD  President Rosanne Somerson 76 ID will be a featured speaker in a session: Critical Making: Making the Future. Alumna Stephanie Silverman 04 FD will receive the Eastern Region Secondary Art Educator Award, and RISD’s Teaching + Learning in Art + Design (TLAD) Head Paul Sproll will make presentations. To top it all off, Alumni Relations will host a reception where you can catch up with faculty members, current students and alumni in town for the convention.  

RISD Reception at the NAEA Conference
Friday, March 27, 2015
6:00 pm – 8:00 pm
International House New Orleans, 221 Camp Street
RSVP to Patricia Brown at pbrown@risd.edu  

LET US KNOW if you are presenting! Email Professor Paul Sproll at psproll@risd.edu and we'll share at www.risdtlad.com. 

You don't need to attend the Conference to come to our reception - if you can make it to New Orleans, we'd love to see you!

event.title: Faculty on the Road with Joanne Stryker in Seattle
event.description_text:
GET SMUDGED AND SPATIAL

Join the RISD/Seattle Alumni Club for an evening of color, shape and critical inquiry. RISD Dean of Foundation Studies Joanne Stryker will share what’s new in the department and across campus.

An Evening with RISD Dean Joanne StrykerMonday, March 30, 20156:30 PM to 8:30 PMOur/Vodka, 1836 NW Market Street, Seattle, WA 

This event is free, but space is limited! Register at https://joannestryker-risdseattle.eventbrite.com  

A Professor of Drawing and Dean of the Division of Foundation Studies, Joanne is a practicing artist and author. She has exhibited her large-scale drawings of cultural artifacts in galleries and museums in New York, Boston, and throughout the United States. She also published a book titled Drawing Structure and Vision with fellow professor, Fritz Drury. The drawing book features the work of many RISD alumni.

Whether you can join us or not, share your charcoal besmudged memories of favorite professors, projects, and first impressions of life at RISD with the hashtag #RISDfoundations.

event.title: RISD Photo TC Colley Lecture Series - Gillian Laub
event.description_text:
Gillian Laub (b. 1975) is a photographer born in Chappaqua New York.  She graduated from the University of Wisconsin-Madison with a degree in comparative literature before studying photography at the International Center of Photography, New York where her love of storytelling and family narratives began. She was selected for the World Press Photo’s Joop Swart Masterclass in 2003 and as the winner of Nikon’s Storyteller Award for her work in the Middle East.  With the support of the Jerome Foundation, Laub’s first monograph Testimony was published by Aperture in 2007 to critical acclaim.  This body of work is comprised of portraits and testimonies from Israeli Jews, Israeli Arabs and Palestinians all directly and indirectly affected by the complicated geopolitical context in which they live. 

In 2007, Laub was awarded Aperture’s Emerging Artist Award.  Gillian Laub has received recognition for her multimedia work. “Take Care”, won first place in FotoWeekDC 2011, was a Webby honoree, and named TIME Magazine’s Top Ten Web Videos of 2010. She was recently a finalist for The Arnold Newman Prize for her multimedia piece “Becoming Nikki” – a project about a transgender youth, who transitioned from male to female at the age of 10 with the support of her family. Laub was recently awarded the Aaron Siskind Individual Photographer’s Fellowship.   She contributes regularly to The New York Times Magazine, TIME Magazine, among many other publications and commissions.  Her work is widely exhibited and collected. She currently lives in New York and is represented by Bonni Benrubi Gallery. 

Gillian Laub’s directorial debut Southern Rites will be premiering on HBO in May 2015.  This documentary feature film explores race in the American South.

event.title: RISD LEADS - Lessons in Leadership from an Exhibit
event.description_text:
Featuring: Daniel Cavicchi, Dean of Liberal Arts at RISD (biography)

In 2007, Daniel Cavicchi was asked by the Recording Academy to take over a floor of its yet-to-be-opened Grammy Museum in downtown Los Angeles and to create a major historical exhibit on music and politics in America. In this session, Dan will share some of the lessons learned in managing such a large-scale public project, from planning how to curate the nation's musical history from scratch to negotiating competing expectations from donors, designers, musicians, funders, and visitors.

Fulfills - Operational, Art + Design

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Iñaki Abalos + Renata Sentkiewicz Lecture
event.description_text:
Ábalos+Sentkiewicz is an international architecture office settled in Madrid (Spain) and Cambridge (US), directed by Iñaki Ábalos and Renata Sentkiewicz.

Iñaki Ábalos and Renata Sentkiewicz have taught in prestigious university centres such as GSD-Harvard University, Architectural Association, Columbia, Cornell, Princeton, ETSAM, combining the academic, professional and research activity. Iñaki Ábalos is currently Chaired Professor at ETSAM- Spain, and Chair of the Department of Architecture- GSD Harvard University-US.

The projects and built work of Ábalos+Sentkiewicz are internationally recognized, have been subject of 15 individual exhibitions and many collective exhibitions in the most prestigious centres, AA-London, Pavillon de l’arsenale-Paris, MoMA- NYC (MoMA has exhibited 5 built works in three different exhibitions: Light construction, ON Site, Groundswell)

event.title: Final date to withdraw from a course, "W" Grade
RISD LEADS - 101 Session
event.description_text:
What is a leader? How do I develop as one?  In this session, participants will explore their own personal experiences and assumptions around leadership to uncover the traits they find both effective and detrimental when trying to become a successful leader.  Through an overview of contemporary research on the topic, participants will discuss identified styles of leadership and how each might be appropriately implemented to get results in a variety of contexts. Individuals will then reflect on their own style and potential as a leader, building a habit of self awareness that will help them achieve their own vision of success. The session will conclude with an overview of the RISD LEADS program and a description of how it can help you achieve success during your individual development as you build up your personal leadership toolkit.

Students who fully enroll in RISD LEADS are required to attend a 101 session to complete the program.

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.description_text:

Participants can expect a combination of interactive dialogue and activity as we critically examine leadership issues within small business, U.S. education, modern families, and workplace environments. We will evaluate our personal experiences within these areas of leadership and discuss the implications of leadership structures on the efficacy of these organizations.

event.title: Open Media and Glass Seniors Exhibition
RISD LEADS - Beginner’s Mind: Risk, Transparency, and Leadership
event.description_text:
Featuring: Jason Huff, Product Design Manager at Etsy, RISD Alum (biography)

Sometimes the opportunity to take the lead can surprise you. Often, the best approach is simply to be open to the wave of new challenges. In this session Digital + Media alumni Jason Huff shares how student leadership at RISD fostered the connections and skills needed to become a successful artist, product designer and now design manager at Etsy. He will discuss the importance of taking on leadership roles in your own work and share stories from his current experience building a design team in a late-stage startup. We'll aim to understand how risk, openness, and transparency form the foundations of good leadership.

Fulfills - Theory, Entrepreneurial Leadership, Art + Design

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Bernard Tschumi Keynote Lecture
event.description_text:
This is the keynote address for the Architecture, Urbanism, Humanities: Intersection of Pedagogies symposium. 

Bernard Tschumi is widely recognized as one of today’s foremost architects. First known as a theorist, he drew attention to his innovative architectural practice in 1983 when he won the prestigious competition for the Parc de La Villette, a 125-acre cultural park based on activities as much as nature. The intertwining concepts of “event” and “movement” in architecture are supported by Tschumi’s belief that architecture is the most important innovation of our time. Tschumi often references other disciplines in his work, such as literature and film, proving that architecture must participate in culture’s polemics and question its foundations. 

Since then, he has made a reputation for groundbreaking designs that include the new Acropolis Museum; Le Fresnoy National Studio for the Contemporary Arts; the Vacheron-Constantin Headquarters; The Richard E. Lindner Athletics Center at the University of Cincinnati; two concert halls in Rouen and Limoges, and architecture schools in Marne-la-Vallée, France and Miami, Florida, as well as the Alésia Archaeological Center and Museum among other projects. The office’s versatility extends to infrastructure projects and master plans. Major urban design projects recently executed or in implementation under Tschumi’s leadership include master plans in Beijing, Shenzhen, New York, Montreal, Chartres, Lausanne, and Santo Domingo, with a new city for 40,000 residents. Currently under construction are the Hague Passage and Hotel in the Netherlands, a Philharmonic Hall for Le Rosey, near Geneva, an expansion of the headquarters for Vacheron Constantin, and a major renovation and redesign of the Paris Zoo. 

 

read more at http://www.tschumi.com

event.title: A Toast to Friedrich St. Florian, Architect and Scholar
event.description_text:
A Toast to Friedrich St. Florian, Architect and ScholarSaturday, April 25, 2015 

The annual RISD Museum Associates fundraiser will be an evening honoring Friedrich St. Florian, to be held at the RISD Museum on Saturday evening, April 25, 2015. The evening will feature a cocktail reception, private viewing of the Museum’s special exhibition Drawing Ambience: Alvin Boyarsky and the Architectural Association, and a gala dinner in the Museum’s Grand Gallery, with remarks by Professor St. Florian.

Tickets to the event are $500 per person. Event sponsorships are available at levels ranging from $1,000 to $10,000. There will also be a program book with advertising opportunities. Proceeds benefit the RISD Museum.

For more information, please contact Pam Kimel, RISD Museum Special Events Manager at 401-454-6505 or pkimel@risd.edu.

event.title: RISD LEADS - WRITE Your Leadership Ethos
event.description_text:
Featuring: Anne West, Senior Lecturer, RISD Graduate Studies (biography)

As artists and designers inspired to action in the world, it is important to work responsively from a place of clear intention. In this one-hour writing workshop, using well-crafted prompts and dialogue, we will reflect on what really matters to us as image and form makers in our culture. The main interest of this workshop is to shape a leadership ethos that is congruent with our values, priorities and motivations. This statement will serve as a living map, to encourage, nurture and sustain mindful leadership as we take agency.

Fulfills - Communication

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.

event.title: Lisa Iwamoto Lecture
event.description_text:
Lisa Iwamoto received her Master of Architecture degree with Distinction from Harvard University, and a Bachelor of Science degree in Structural Engineering from the University of Colorado. She has worked as a Structural Engineer at Bechtel Corporation, and Architectural Designer at Schwartz Silver Architects, Thompson and Rose, and Architectural Intern at Morphosis. She has taught previously at the University of Michigan where she was a Muschenheim Fellow, Harvard University, Cornelll University and Southern California Institute of Architecture. She is currently Full Professor at University of California Berkeley where her design research concentrates on the perceptual performance of material and digital fabrication techniques.

iwamotoscott.com

event.title: RISD LEADS - On the Comeback Trail: A Panel Discussion with the Leaders of the City of Central Falls
event.description_text:
Featuring: Central Falls Mayor, James Diossa, and Central Falls Director of Planning and Economic Development, Stephen Larrick (biographies)

What does a position of leadership mean in times of conflict and public disillusionment? How do you move forward with limited resources and create strategy to turn around a failed system? The current leadership of Central Falls, Rhode Island is doing just that. Join Mayor James Diossa and Director of Planning and Economic Development Stephen Larrick in this panel discussion about leadership in the "comeback city," Central Falls.

Fulfills - Community

While RISD LEADS is offered as a certificate program, Sessions are open to anyone who is interested. You do not have to fully enroll in the LEADS program to attend sessions. Formal entry can be done at any time and credit is given for past attendance. 

Whether you are interested in formally enrolling in the RISD LEADS program or want to sample specific sessions, this semester's series will provide you with wonderful opportunities and enrichment.
